captions.text:
Dude, what is with the Easy Buttons?
I thought you were gonna get, like, the receptionist

bell, so we could do the dings like from the
sins videos.

I looked man. I don't know where to find those
things. I don't know what store sells those.

We can't debate movies and keep score using
an easy button. That's beyond lame. People

will think we're stupid.
Well this is the best I could do, okay, so

do you wanna do it, or complain about it?
Okay.

Okay, so let's talk about The Hobbit.
Let's talk about the Hobbit.

The Hobbit sucks!
Why does The Hobbit suck?

The Hobbit sucks because of all the goofy
sh*t.

Goofy sh*t?
The snot, the body noises, the wacky f*cking

brown wizard.
This movie is silly as f*ck.

Okay, I will grant you that there are some
moments in the movie that are a little bit

silly.
"That was easy."

Point for me.
Okay. My turn. The Gollum scene.

Let's hear you say something bad about the
Gollum scene.

Even an idiot like you has to know how awesome
that scene was.

Let's hear you say it was bad.
I wanna hear it.

Come on.
Come on.

I can't argue that. I can't.
"That was easy."

Exactly. Thank you.
You happy now?

Yeah, I'm happy now.
The dishes song.

The dishes song is in the book!
No, no. No movie that takes a tiny ass book

and splits it out into three movies and then
fills it with all kinds of filler sh*t that

wasn't actually there? That movie doesn't
get to claim 'It was in the book' when I criticize.

That movie has left the book behind a long
time ago.

Another problem with the dishes song is this.
I cannot believe that didn't break.

Exactly! There's no way those dwarfs could
have done that without breaking all the dishes.

"That was easy."
It's dwarves.

What?
It's dwarves, not dorfs.

"That was easy."
That's not even a point about the movie.

I don't care. I score a point every time you're
a moron.

Now let's talk about the action, because it
was awesome.

No it isn't! The action is kid-friendly. It's
stupid. It's like a dumbed-down version of

what Middle Earth action ought to be. And
that's stupid.

"That was easy."
You can't just score a point without any debate.

Yes I can.
No you can't.

And I just did.
What are you gonna do about it?

I guess I'm gonna sit here and--
Alright the other problem is the bloat.

The what?
The bloat.

The bloat?
This movie has so much unnecessary scenery,

this movie has so many unnecessary characters.
It's ridiculous. To prove my point, I brought

somebody else to help us, to discuss it.
You brought somebody else?

Geez, dude you know I freakin' hate this guy.
Why do you have to bring this guy? We don't

need him to debate movies. He doesn't add
anything.

Exactly!
Tell me this isn't exactly how you felt when

Frodo showed up and did nothing.
Tell me this isn't exactly how you felt when

Elrond and Galadriel, the masters of boredom,
had a 15 minute conference with Gandalf.

Tell me this isn't exactly how you felt when
the mother f*cker shows up on a sled drawn

by rabbits!
If I agree with you will you tell him to go?

Yeah.
Get rid of him?

Alright the rabbits are stupid.
The rabbits are dumb.

"That was easy."
Alright, so get rid of him.

He's not that bad, really. I mean, he's a
little slow, but--

We made a deal.
He sure is friendly.

We made a deal, you said you were gonna get
rid of him.

We did. But have you ever tried getting rid
of this guy? It's next to impossible.

Then why did you even invite him over in the
first place.

Can you at least tell him to stop staring
at me like that.

Hey! You're bothering him!
Can I come in? Hello?

title: Conversations With Myself About Movies - The Hobbit

comments.text:
I expected a longer video with more arguments in favor of the hobbit but I 
guess Jeremy didn't like so... But again great video ;)﻿
comments.author: Donnie Lover

comments.text:
I don't think the silliness counts against the movie(s). The book is silly, 
it is not Lord of the Rings and so many people seem to forget that when 
criticising it.﻿
comments.author: atomicmrpelly

comments.text:
I think peter Jackson planed out the storyline then was like "Oh fudge! I 
can't do that in one movie!"
comments.author: F. Jinxy

comments.text:
I seriously do almost hate Frodo. I can't explain it. He's just incredibly 
boring. And the borderline gay interactions between him and Sam are 
unbearable. Either be bold enough to make them gay and say it outright, or 
leave it alone.

On the other hand, I love Bilbo. He's funny, exciting, and just all around 
more pleasant. And I just love Martin Freeman as an actor in both The 
Hobbit and Sherlock, which may cause some bias, but I enjoyed reading The 
Hobbit far more than LOTR, so I'm not entirely sure.

Personally, I think Tolkien spent way too many pages/chapters of talking. 
Or merrymaking. Or describing of scenery. Like it's great he can make a 
world and describe it as if he's actually been there, but I don't care that 
the Road winds around a hill, especially if the party is wandering through 
the forest, avoiding the Road. That said, I think greed is what drove The 
Hobbit being made into a trilogy. At most, it was enough for 2 movies with 
a total runtime of about 5 hours, but 8 hours from one book is ridiculous.

comments.text: Too true.

absolutely *nothing* to the story whatsoever. It was totally unnecessary 
and served as nothing more than a distraction in the continuity of Bilbo's 
narrative.

I was so disappointed in this offering from Peter Jackson it left me 
wanting. I remember telling a friend the very same thing and he asked what 
it was that I was wanting. My reply - "my money back" :s

comments.author: Matthew Faller

comments.text:
+Matthew Faller I was wondering about the exposure as well until the guy 
popped up in the window. That's why the exposure is the way it is. So that 
we can get at least some definition outside the window while we're inside. 
Yes you could have added more lights inside to compensate but if you're on 
a short schedule or don't own a bunch of lights this is a decent way to be 
able to see what is outside and inside at the same time.

have liked it. But everyone takes the movie out of context either because 
a.) they haven't read the book, and don't understand the fun-loving 
context, especially after seeing the LOTR movies or b.) the movie really 
did go over-the-top with stupid shit like the rabbits and even going so far 
as to unnecessarily do stuff like messing up the Azog/Bolg timeline (Azog 
in the movie is like Bolg in the book, only in the movie, Bolg's ("Azog's") 
father isn't mentioned.    ﻿

comments.author: rlrsk8r1

comments.text:
Nerd moment here!

Actually, both "dwarfs" and "dwarves" are completely acceptable. Take a 
look at similar plurals ending in -f: leaf, roof, hoof. The common rule is 
to drop the -f and form the plural -ves, BUT in England they have not 
always observed this. In the last century, English schools saw a sharp 
trend toward a simple plural, so much so that the simple -s plural became 
completely acceptable.

Today, the United States is following suit. Even Disney calls its first 
feature film "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," a break from its earlier 
naming convention.

Compare this to the word "leaf." Its plural is "leaves," in the US, but 
Toronto's hockey team forms the plural "leafs."

Once again, Jeremy, this is an example of a British-ism. It is quickly 
becoming accepted and proper in the US, so much so that I believe we can 
say it's fine either way.

And that's your nerd moment for the day.﻿

Not really. Tolkien never intended for the book to be a children's book. He

Jackson made the movie.

comments.author: James Robin

comments.text:
Some people might hate this, but I prefer not to think of the ongoing 
Jackson project as a film interpretation of "The Hobbit" (The singular 
book), but rather, as Jackson's interpretation of a period of time in 
Tolkien's Legnedarium which happens to revolve around the events of "The 
Hobbit". I say interpretation because of course a film adaption will alter 
certain things. Also, any true Tolkien/LOTR film trilogy fan would 
absolutely love that they're throwing in the additional stuff, especially 
the conflict with Sauron. That "stuff" is like nerd-galore. Don't think of 
it as a method to cash in, but instead as a visual bonus to the great 
material that we've read and enjoyed. After that, hate the plot and CGI all 
you want, that's a completely different realm of argument. ﻿

comments.author: AllyDash

comments.text:
When there's a trilogy about 1 book everybody loses their minds about the 
fact that there is story being told which might not exist in the book. But 
when you do the opposite, as in Harry Potter where you have almost the same 
amount of films as the books, everybody suddenly complains about the fact 
that filmmakers decides to exclude some of the story because of not enough 
running film time for these excluded scenes to fill in. Then, if they 
would've added 2 more films people would think of the production company as 
idiots looking to earn more money but instead it might be because of the 
fact that there were vital parts that needed to be included in the films to 
understand.

Legolas did not have a role in the book, but in the film he had, because it 
made perfect sense that he should've been there! And as of all the rest of 
the problems people complain about, get over it. It's done. Peter Jackson 
can do whatever the fuck he wanna do. 

So my conclusion is:

Be frikkin' happy about that there's 3 movies instead of 1 or 2. Goddamnit, 
Peter Jackson is making it possible for us viewers to enter the incredible 
world of Tolkien for a longer period of time! Stop complaining.﻿

comments.author: mriswithmoo

comments.text:
+Emmhelie Sherrell
Did you just call someone stupid for not agreeing with you on a matter of 
taste? Yeah, that's a really smart move.

Look, I'm a huge LoTR and Hobbit fan myself, and a somewhat rare one in 
that I actually dig both the moves and the books. They're different and 
both have their upisdides and downsides. The movies look awesome, but they 
also do have their weaknesses for sure. +Taylorwest626 did makes valid 
points about it: the main villain is very bland and unneseccary, and the 
movies overall have a lot of bloat in them, a part of which is caused by 
the studio going over the top and wanting to play with the 3D gimmickry.

Whilist I did enjoy the movies in a casual way (that is,I don't take the 
Hobbit movies too seriously, I appreciate them for the aesthetic and the 
few very extremely awesome bits) I can totally understand why a lot of the 
Tolkien fanbase doesn't. And I don't go around the internet telling people 
who don't like them that they're stupid for not sharing my views any more 
than I go around telling people they're "stupid" for not liking the same 
bands that I like.

People have varying preferences when it comes to art. Deal with it.
